answers.answerText: A. Blood from a vitreous hemorrhage
B. Inflammatory cells from a uveitis
C. None, this is just imaging artefact
D. Calcium lipid complexes in the vitreous
answers.explanation:
The OCT shows hyper-reflective dots in the vitreous (highlighted in red) with a shadowing effect (highlighted in blue) on the retina. These findings, in combination with the fundoscopy, is very suggestive of asteroid hyalosis (AH). There are no signs in the patient history suggestive of a vitreous hemorrhage, such as floaters, or vision loss. As well, the slit lamp and fundus examination was otherwise normal with no evidence of uveitis. There is also no reason to believe that the area highlighted in red below is an imaging artefact, especially in the context of the fundus findings in the right eye. 

![](/content/media/r58_3.webp)

answers.explanation:
Blood, inflammatory cells, and calcium-lipid complexes are hyper-reflective on OCT and can appear in the vitreous in the conditions listed above.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered to be a risk factor for the development of asteroid hyalosis?

answers.explanation:
A link between asteroid hyalosis and the other conditions listed above has been established already. There is no known relationship between high myopia and AH. Other risk factors associated with AH are high serum calcium and cardiovascular disease.

References:

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: Which of the following statements about Asteroid Hyalosis is FALSE?

answers.answerText: A. Most of the time it is asymptomatic
B. Cataract surgery in the context of AH is usually uncomplicated and a silicone IOL should be used
answers.explanation:
While asteroid hyalosis does not usually severely affect vision, the floating opacities can interfere significantly with the examination of the retina. As AH changes the optical quality of the vitreous, it can interfere with readings from automated technologies such as autorefraction, A-scan ultrasonography, axial length measurements, and IOL power calculations. However, the performance of cataract surgery itself has not been reported to be influenced by the presence of AH. Of note, however, silicone IOLs can calcify when implanted in eyes with asteroid hyalosis, making silicone an unacceptable material choice for these subjects. 

References:

Sebag J. Vitreous anatomy and pathology. In: Yanoff M, Duker JM. Ophthalmology. Philadelphia: Mosby, 1999. 8.47.1 8.

Khoshnevis M, Rosen S, Sebag J. Asteroid hyalosis-a comprehensive review. Surv Ophthalmol. 2019 Jul-Aug;64(4):452-462. doi: 10.1016/j.survophthal.2019.01.008. Epub 2019 Jan 30. PMID: 30707924.

title: Case 58
description: 51M presenting for routine eye exam with normal vision OU
patientPresentation:
**Contributor:** Bridget Moran (Trinity College Dublin Medical Student)

A 51-year-old male presents for a routine eye examination with no visual complaints. He denies a history of floaters or vision loss. BCVA is 20/20 OU and IOP is within normal limits OU. Slit-lamp examination is normal in both eyes with no evidence of uveitis. Fundus examination of the left eye is normal, while examination of the right eye reveals yellow-white particles in the vitreous (shown below). The rest of the fundus examination was normal. 

![](/content/media/r58_1.webp)

OCT was subsequently performed on the right eye.
